element_texts.text:
2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.
Nov 4, 1951
Dear Jacks -

 The esteemed Ku Klux has been active hereabouts of late - A couple of weeks ago they places a fiery cross and a burning "K" in front of one of

one of the many local whorehouses, this one prettily named "Gay Cove". The imperturbable whores showed no particular alarm and business continued brisk despite the incendiary, somewhat wistful protest.

 The other day we found two more charred "K's" alongside a highway where we were working. There was also a wooden sign stuck into the ground, with a crudely

lettered, rather puzzling message, which said, in effect: "Resolved, that the U.N. flag shall not fly over Old Glory! Tear down all U.N. flags!"

 Shows progress in a way, from harrassing simple-minded prostitutes to global-mindedness, however muddled. World unrest must be deep indeed if it can penetrate to such a subterranean level.
 I suggested kicking the whole stupid apparatus into the weeds, and one of the shot-gun guards, properly spooked, cautioned me against disturbing it.  Which would 

indicate, I guess, that the outfit still has a strong hold down here among the cracker-type characters, who are legion. The state KKK Grand Dragon is a candidate in the forthcoming election for governor. It will be interesting to see

  (over)

-2-

how many votes he polls.

 Here is a regional story for you, one which was received by the southern members of the crew with much merriment and slapping of thighs:
   An old colored preacher was ordered by the local constable to cease holding roadside revival meetings, on the grounds that he was obstructing traffic. He declared, to his deacon, that he was working for the Lord, and was going to continue, constable or no.  Half-way through the meeting, the deacon saw the constable coming and took to the woods. Coming back later, he found the preacher along, beaten and bleeding. Said the deacon,
  "You say you is workin' for de Lawd?"
  "Sho I is," said the preacher.
  "And do de Lawd know about dem white folks beatin' you all up de side ob de haid like dat?"
  " Sho, he do."
  " Den why don't he do sumpin about it?"
  " He jes' don't give a damn, that's why!'

 Enjoyed the Macaulay "Orphan Island" very much. The theme is apparently one which has had considerable appeal to various writers since Swift. The most 

memorable job recently has been Orwell's "Animal Farm", which I always enjoy re-reading. ("All animals are equal, but some are more equal than others.")

                                Yours,
                                Jim Blake

P.S. Any chance of laying hands on that Holiday
containing Algren's article? Limpid and lucid, that boy.

    JB

-3-

P.S.  If you have any old New Yorkers, I should appreciate receiving them. I am in great need of a laugh having
almost forgotten how, and I should like to obey the poet's adjuration -

   Thou shalt not live within thy means
   Nor on plain water and raw greens.
   If thou must choose
   Between the chances, choose the odd;
   Read the New Yorker, trust in God;
   And take short views.

                      JB.

April 28, 1951

 This is something I am ashamed of doing. it is easier for me to steal than to beg, which is perhaps why I am here - but desperation makes me

bold, so I am asking if you can contribute, as a short loan, five dollars to my Liberation Fund - I am serving the seventy month of a two year sentence in this
Dixie dungeon, and I am making plans to hang it up and make my way back through the Union lines -

 Bud has been enormously helpful, and with the money he has sent, I am going to grease a cooperative shot-gun guard of the chain-gang I was in,

but I am in need of some money for civilian clothing to negotiate the perilous passage between here and the Mason-Dixon iron curtain.

 Perhaps if I can give you an idea of what I have been through, you will understand my urgent desire to be altogether elsewhere - not since Oliver Twist 

has anybody taken such a pasting from a perverse Fate -

 Every day I go out with a work gang at sun-up to work on the roads with two shot-gun guards or to quarry sand or line-rock, or to dig ditches through

snake-infested swamps while fighting off clouds of s tinging sand-gnats. Months of this heat-tearing labor has made me physically as lean and muscular
as a hound, but the mental torture I have undergone at the hands of cursing half-drunken guards has been formidable

                     (over)

And it doesn't end with the day - At night the prisoners all sleep in a large dormitory and aberrant sex, perouous? and savage, is rife. I have been forced to choose
a "protector" in this grotesque game, and ex-pugilist with a background of varied incarcerations, who, though flamboyantly handsome, is viciously narcissive
and sadistic. This strange arrangement has resulted in beatings, pummelings and arm-twistings until I feel that I am trapped, unable to awake, in some endless nightmare.
In the sex thing, I have always been a party of pale passions, a dilletante and a dabbler in the shallows, and this disastrous plunge into such a storm of violent and
primitive emotions has caused me often to fear for my mental balance. As it is, most of the time I am actually physically sick from fear and apprehension.

 It sounds horribly overblown and melodramatic, I know, but the truth as calmly and quietly as I can tell it is that I must get away or I do not know what will happen. Much more of this I cannot take.
 Please write, Jack, mail is the one contact I have with a same world I have almost forgotten exists. Incoming mail is not opened and I am "flying" this letter out.
            Sincerely,
              Jim Blake.

May 20, 1951.
Dear Jack -

 Thank you for your contribution to the Blake - must - Go Funds - I am still proceeding cautiously with my plans for the big bang-up, always mindful that the penalty for failure is another year here (half the original time) and Dixie bracelets for my ankles - But it looks pretty good - One of the trusties took off for the wild blue yonder last night, the joint is buzzing, and again I must give them time to simmer down.
 The initial shocks of the horrific labor they pile on you here has worn off somewhat, and eight months of it has hardened me considerably, but I still tumble into my

bunk pretty well dead-beat at night - And after lights-out in the dormitory the brutal and vicious sex practises make any games I may have played with the Merry Androgynes of
East Division Street seem pale and restful indeed. When I get out of this, I swear I shall be ascetic as Grandma Moses - nothing else could have purged me of my aberrations so
violently and thoroughly. I'm turning in my beanie, and the sorority will see me no more

 Sorry to hear of the obtuseness of your publishers - The Rosewood Casket: A Garland of Rue and Lavender is a provocative title, and I should have imagined it would sell.
 Have your read Love In a Cold Climate by Nancy Mitford? It's been our for some time, over a year, I guess, and is lightly malicious high comedy. One of the most entertaining things               (over)

I've run across in a good while.

 When I first came in here I started work on a play, the idea for which had been bouncing around in my mind for a while. I wanted to keep my mind active, and divert it

from my troubles and all the sordid dullness around me, but the effort at concentration was too great, and the beating I was taking took the heart out of me - But I'd still
like to finish it when I get out, if only because I think I have something to say about musicians and entertainers and homosexuals that hasn't been said. Then too, of course,
I enjoy doing it. It's called A Tinkling Piano, about a two-piano team, based on characters I've known, like Jimmy Page and Gwen Paul, among others. Gwen was certainly
an unforgettable, robust, ribald, beautiful soul with a flair for jazz, and a perception that many musicians cannot equal.

 I have another project left unfinished in Chicago that I'd like to get back to. I was working with a young composer, a brilliant guy on a play called Season in Hell, built around the scandalous and tragi-comic affair between the two poets Verlaine and Rimbaud. Some of the music, tone-poems on Rimbaud's Illuminations, was already written,

when we had a temperamental tohu-bohu and quit. But I still think it's a fantastic and moving little story, and that there's a play in it, as the agents say.

 I would certainly appreciate a copy of Midland Humor, if you want to trouble to send it, Jack. I remember skipping through it once and liking what I saw. Thanks again for your kindness, and I hope you will write soon.
                   Sincerely,
                     Jim Blake

2635 Commonwealth Av.
Jax, Fla.
on side:   P.S. The duplication of the letters I wrote you was merely to insure one of them getting out. Underground mailing is rather uncertain.

June 4, 1951.
Dear Jack -

 Many thanks for your delightful anthology, Midland Humor, and especially for the charming inscription. The criminal master-minds who share my lot were quite awed by it, and it has given me quite a cachet in the mayhem - and - mopery set. They seem to think that an author belongs somewhere in the social scale between a preacher and a moonshiner, which in Dixie is not as large a gap as you might suppose.
 I've been skipping around in your book, and so far have particularly enjoyed Wilcox's With Everything So Scarce, McKinney's No Tears, No Good.
and Balch's Momma Gest and the Irisher. The Peter De Vries story was well-done too, I thought, and your "Sissy" was entertaining.
 Algren's story has an incisive bite, as does all his stuff - The Shulman was very familiar to me from several readings of his book.
 Incidentally, what did Shulman ever have to say, if anything, about the contemptuous, and, to me, 
                                   (over)

unexplicable dismissal that Fadiman gave his last book?

 Thanks again, it was an extremely thoughtful gift, and has already provided some much needed lighter moments.
             Sincerely,
               Jim Blake

2635 Commonwealth Av
Jacksonville, Fla

Dear Jack - 
I have only now managed to [corral?] some writing material, as I would have written sooner to thank you for the book of short stories, "Cross-Section." I enjoyed it very much, particularly "[Zaunchi?] the Chicken" by Eli Waldrow, and Richard Wright's "Early Days in Chicago." Many of the stories, I noticed," are written in the truncated, headless-and-legless style made popular, almost mandatory, by the New Yorker. As for the poems, the preface says they are [obscurantist?], and I am ready to go along with that.
As always, reading any contemporary writing always fires me with a desire to try my hand at it once again. I am bursting into the things I want to say, but my prose always comes out bearing an eerie resemblance to that of Eleanor Roosevelt

in her daily column, and that it is enough to dash anybody. And yet when I submit anything to friends whose judgment I trust, and they tell me, sadly but with quiet satisfaction, that I simply cannot write, I am infuriated, and realize that I was a fool ever to think that anyone of them had the perception of a pig.
I have made an effort to escape from here, and it was a [prison?]. Bud will give you the details, if you are interested, I did like to dwell on the painful episode.
Anything else you may have to read I hope you will send on. An ocean of time stretches out before me, and reading is the only escape I can look forward to for a long time.
Thank you again, Jack, for your kind thoughtfulness.
Sincerely,
Jim Blake
2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.

August 16, 1951
Dear Jack -
The usual hassle over procuring a stamp and envelope has kept me from writing sooner to thank you for the two books you sent.
I particularly enjoyed "Caliban," a deft and witty thing, written with such a wealth of detail that I was led to speculate on whether it was a thinly-veiled account of the rise to power of [Beaverbrook?]. I was amused by Bulmer's descriptions of his two sisters as "embroidering table scarves for people who had never done them any harm." A pretty funny book, and an absorbing story.
The other, by Elizabeth Bowen, was one of those English novels about the Riviera I have always liked, gentle and comfortable, along the line of Stern's "Oldeander River" or Margery Shay's "Nutmeg Tree." Bowen has a sharp and shrewd eye for the miniscular in human motivations and relationships. 
(over)

-2-
In fact, it seems that quite a few of my favorite writers are women. I've always liked Stern, although she takes an unconscionable time getting it said occasionally. And she always had a respect for the tales of 'Rumen Goddan?] and Rosamond Schuman. (I once wrote a review for a school paper of Schuman's "A Note in Music." My critique was almost mystically unintelligible, chiefly because I had only a dim idea of what the book was about, and it had a great succes [??] time).
The BBC scripts in "The Listener" sound interesting and I should very much like to read them. And if you can conveniently come by a Pocket-Book edition of a dictionary or thesaurus, I could make good use of it. My vocabulary is a source of pride and astonishment to me, and I'd kind of like to know what it all means.
The Po' Man's Prometheus,
Jim Blake
2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.

Sept 30, 1951
Dear Jack -
Many thanks for the dictionary, the [Eleanor?] Wylie, and the British periodicals, particularly the delightful Punch almanac [number?].
About the Wylie opus, The Orphan Angel, I am slightly puzzled. What I want to know is, is she kidding? [?a], sir, such stylish writing, such sixteen-cylinder prose!
Somewhere between such literary marzipan and the barracks-room utilitarianism of James Jones lies the golden mean, I guess. A giant of the past has this to say about his own work - "I fear chiefly lest my expression may not be extra-vagant enough, may not wander for enough beyond the narrow limits of my daily experience, so as to be adequate to the truth of which I have been convinced - Why level downward to our dullest perception always, and praise that as common sense? The commonest sense is the sense of men asleep, which they express by morning."
Anyway, I enjoyed the Wylie book, although it was quite a bit of whipped cream.
Reading The Listener has given me a fairly comprehensive picture of British radio and I could
(over)

-2-
wish that radio here would strive for such a laudable cultural level. Some of the scripts seemed formidably esoteric to me, so I was relieved somewhat when I read in Punch a satiric lampooning of some typical BBC shows. Made me feel less marooned in the outer darkness, a luckless peasant all ignorant of Mrs. Humphrey Ward. Even so, now I know who she was and something of what she wants. And now, of course, like an [ark?] seeking a mate, I must find somebody who also knows about Mrs. Humphrey Ward, so that we can chat.
Any reading material you care to send is welcome, Jack, as you know, and it will save me from having to read those paper-backed historical novels which abound here. I don't mean the drum-and-trumpet school. The lads here call such books, with an honest simplicity that the book business could use, "fuck-books."
I am enclosing what I think is one of the most truly hilarious short stories ever. The writer is an Englishman about whom you may be more informed than I am. I only know he is a sweetheart, and that you will enjoy it.
Yours,
Jim Blake
2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.
P.S. If you have a copy of Nathaniel West's "The Day of the Locust," and are willing to lend it, I have always wanted to read it.

Dec. 10, 1951
Dear Jack - 
Thank you for the Punch and the Listeners, and most especially for Elizabeth Bowen's The Heat of the Day. I found it a disturbing and spell-binding story. Bowen takes you on a strange journey, threading her way expertly among the shifting webs and folds of human consciousness - I put it down with some of the feeling of emerging from a somber dream. And one thing that a character in the books said will stay with me for some time - "Look at your free people* - mice let loose in the middle of the Sahara." Hard to shake off.
I enjoyed the article in the Listener, Claw of the Sea Press by [Homer?] Tracy, apparently reprinted from a talk on the BBC. It is somehow reassuring to me to find that England the U.S. have [Thurber?] in common. The English excel in high comedy - but I think the New Yorker is on the whole funnier than Punch. The deft and amusing analysis of [Thurber?] came off well - after all, analyzing anybody's humor can be a pretty precarious undertaking. The thing is liable to turn on you, or worse still, just lay there.
What a pity that radio here is in the hands of those glib and glass-brained mediocrities, the Agency People.
(over)

By "free people" it should not be supposed I mean those who are not in jail. In discussing freedom, of whatever degree, I realize my position is at the moment, somewhat vulnerable.

-2-
The only thing I've heard on the radio that seems to be aimed at something other than morons is the Ronald Colman program Halls of Ivy and the script of that is self-conscious and lumbering when it is not unbearably arch - Quotations from Byron, Chaucer, etc., introduced with all the grace of a hen landing on the water.
About four years ago, there was a series of broadcasts over WILL, the University of Illinois station at Champaign. Most memorable were the lectures, direct from the classroom of some ribald old gent in the English department who spoke on the Restoration and Elizabethan periods, as I recall. Delivered in a bland and academic tone were some of the most hair-raising things ever to come over the air-waves. And not only amusing, but unfortunate. But that might be called almost "bootleg" culture. Maybe it was allowed only because it reached so few.
Here, there is no change. Still diggin' and dyin', but I get out the end of next May, so I try to possess my soul in patience.
Whenever I get the chance, I talk to some of the Negro trusties around here. Without being too Gallup-ish about it, I've tried to get their opinions on the time-honored Southern attitudes and customs. They are as shy as antelopes, but some of the things they've told me might surprise, possibly even disturb, the Sons of the Carpet-Baggers. But more of that later.
Yours,
Jim Blake
2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.

2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.
Feb. 10, 1952
Dear Jack -
Thanks ever so much for the English magazines and L.A.G. Strong's delightful books. "The Garden" is a lovingly-drawn nostalgic picture of a time and place now regrettably gone - It gave me several hours of esc--e from my present dingy milieu. I especially liked the character whose mission in life was harrying the Salvation Army by following them about and intoning "Whoremongers" at them.
I like also the literary reviews in The Listener. They are more thoughtful and gentle than their American counterparts, it seems to me, less agressively clever. American reviewers seem too often to be less concerned with a considered critical estimate than they are hell-bent to display their own superior erudition - and since it is not difficult to be wittily brilliant by being sardonic at the expense of some upstart author, they too often fall back on the flip quip, the easy slander.
I have in mind particularly an article on F. Scott Fitzgerald by a J. Fielding I read in the New
(over)

Yorker. Although Liebling is not a qualified critic, more of a pamphleteer really, he launched a devastating attack on Fitzgerald, which at first blush seemed to dispose forever of the unfortunate author, and I was enraged at the unfairness of it. But on further consideration, I took comfort at the thought that it is easy for mediocre earthbound minds to [swipe? snipe?] at those who try to soar.
Nevertheless, I resolved to scrutinize carefully anything further that Liebling wrote. I hadn't long to wait. In recent New Yorkers, he had a series of articles on Chicago, perfect examples of the snide, the shallow, and the imperfectly informed. Instead of being overjoyed that there could exist a city and a region whose opinions and attitudes were healthily divergent from those of New York (and, mirabile dictu, immune to the deadly leveling effect of national radio), he decried and disparaged them in shrill tones.
Algnew calls Liebling a "fat mutt." With that beautiful and blunt boot-in-the-rear I'll concur.
I hear that Scribners has had to postpone the sale of the Gutenberg Bible because the sale of James Jones' "From Here to Prosperity" has put them into a higher tax brackets.
Well, I am amassing a collection of pungent words from my fellow male actors, and I am going to do a chain-gang opus that will confound the publishing world. Get out the asterisks, hyah ah come!
But [alors?], Blake.
P.S. Jack, would you mind mailing me a copy of the Chicago Trib (daily) and then Chicago Sun? J.B.

Nov. 25, 1952
Dear Jack -
I assume I have you to thank for the mysterious and most welcome daily appearance of the Chicago Tribune. Doing good by stealth, are you? Herewith, my sincere thanks. Reading the paper every day reminds me sharply of something I had forgotten, that a calm acceptance of assorted violence and death is a part of Chicago living. I fear I shall find that tracks a triple fast after the sheltered life of the chain gang.
The last batch of English magazines was a delight, particularly the Books Number of the Listener, and the London Opinions. I find it hard to put my fingers on the exact quality of the literary reviews in the Listener that makes them so different from their American counterparts - Perhaps it is their aura of graciousness, of good faith, good will.
At any rate, I enjoyed the urbane and gently devastating job that [Hesheth?] Pearson did on St. John Ervine for Ervine's book on Oscar Wilde. He also demolishes Andre Gide and his book on the same subject, but demolishing Gide seems to be a popular sport at present. Poor Andre has fallen on evil days, and surely doesn't deserve it.
(over)

-2-
The review by William Plomer of certain English publications of American humor, shed some light on the English sense of humor, and I was somewhat reassured to find that they laugh at many of the same things we do. (Incidentally, Plomer calls present-day English humor "anaemic," an opinion in which I am forced to concur after reading the London Opinion and Punch)
But I was plunged back into bafflement when Plomer called S.J. Perelmans' latest, "bad-tempered, arrogant and vulgar." I would agree that Perelman's stuff is sometimes labored, but "arrogant"? I'm mystified.
[V.?U.?]S. Pritchett's penetrating and sympathetic article on Spain was excellent, I thought. When I get out of here, I intend to become better acquainted with his works.
About the magazine "Quiver," the less said the better. I presume you included it to show that American magazines have no monopoly on mediocrity. I read an installment of one of the serials, and it is straight soap-opera, everybody in a lather.
The picture, in London Opinion, of a young lady with exposed mammaries astonished me and sent my cell-mate, an amiable mongoloid, into transports. She now adorns the wall beside his bunk. A far journey and strange destination.
Thank you again, Jack. You are surpassing thoughtful.
As ever,
Jim Blake
2635 Commonwealth Ave.
Jacksonville, Fla.

April 27, 1952
Dear Jack - 
Enjoyed the Rose Macaulay "Told By An Idiot" very much. The lady has a deadly aim. And in telling a comprehensive and illuminating tale of the period from late Victorian to World War I she manages, with lethal gentility, to slit a number of gullets. Nice light malice, and some satisfactory assassination.
I liked her account of the critic who hailed Hall Caine's advent as the Second Coming, and then deciding he had been wrong, changed his name, unable to go on living under such a handicap. They took those things more seriously in those days - I don't look for the subsequent career of James Jones, for instance, to being on a rash of aliases in the critical fraternity - But that is prophecy, not only risky but impertinent.
I've been reading the Short novels of Colette - Hers is a perfumed and feverish indoor world, where loving and being loved is of terrible crushing importance. Her small canvases are shrewdly and deftly done, with a kind of astringent compassion, and full of sudden flashes: "Chere, devoid of humour, came up against Lea's pleasantry like an ant against a piece of coal." Damn the woman!
And I, a silly wretch in a constant turmoil of infatuation
(over)

-2-
for one creature or another, go through her books in an ecstasy of sympathy pangs for the doomed and damned lovers. Some ball. If ever I rise to such emotional heights as an appendectomy, I'll be a menace.
By chance or design, I seem to be concerned with the works of monstrously clever women - The poems of Marianne Moore have also been giving me a great deal of pleasure. "The Hero," for instance:
"We do not like some things, and the hero
doesn't; deviating head stones
and uncertainty;
going where one does not wish
to go; suffering and not
saying so; standing and listening where something
is hiding."
Glorious, almost frightening.
Even so, I refuse to be intimidated or deterred by these god-like dedicated beings - I want to write, and I have a touching belief that if I belabour the language long and rigorously enough, I shall one day beat it into submission. Out of all this will emerge my masterpiece, limp and cowed.
I send you greetings from the Valley of the Mongoloids, all shaved and show.
All forlorn,
Blake.

Nov. 13, 1952
Dear Jack - 
Where are you, shy wahn? I do not hear.
I've been told that the issue of Temps Moderne containing The Emotions of an American Nothing is out, and that you, touched by angels, have seen it. Do you know where I can get a copy?
I read Tennessee Williams' Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone recently and haven't been so impressed by anything in a long time - the fresh imagery, the unabashed lyricism[s?], the flow and motion of it - and nowhere the stale and assured glibness of so many established ones.
How did the election suit? We are all going underground, and would love to have you. Bring your bicycle, and some bread and cheese.
Yours,
Jim Blake
Box 31,
Oconomowoc, Wis.

Pinellas County Jail, 3-W
Clearwater,
Fla.
Jan 5, 53
Dear Nelson -
I'll make this brief and to the point, omitting tears. I'm in again, on a tea rap, and looking at five years in Raiford, because of the previous Miami conviction. My trial date has not been set yet, but beating the rap looks pretty remote.
How it happened - Two dicks blew in on me with a search warrant for morphine, saying someone at Bayou Saw had informed them I was shipping junk to one of the addicts living there. Knowing I was clean of any junk, I wasn't worried but I forgot about the remainder of the tea seeds I had stashed in a Band-Aid can. Pour!
Caught that cold, what could I do?

-2-
One of the clowns picked up my manuscript, read it, complimented me. (How nice, a discerning meathead.) Which will explain all the ape-shit in the enclosed article. They had a homo-tag all set to bang on me too, if the junk rap didn't stick, but when they found the tea, they settled for a clear-cut issue. Minimum [?] second conviction is 5 years. So.
Now I know I'll have plenty of time with no distractions, to finish the opus in record (?) time. If you will furnish me some paper and pencils, I will set to, since my possessions are not in my possession. The MS. may just possibly give somebody hereabouts hot shit! But there is nothing, I've always said, like writing on location.
I'd hold off informing Madeleine of the debacle, as not to giggle negotiations, but actually chances of completion are enhanced, and a steady income in my present spot while I work on it, would be the essence, however small the income would be. My room and board are now assured for a while.
This will sound hellish familiar but if you have any loot you can waft with ease can use, since we eat only three daily and then sparsely (some parsley) [match?] food is for sale. Otherwise, I am well and unhappy. Love to you and Amanda. Tonight you seem heart-breakingly remote. Jim

Blake,
c/o Roger's Memorial Sanitarium
Oconomowoc, Wis.
This side of card is for Address
Jack Conroy
6012 S. Green St.
Chicago 21,
Ill

Dear Jack - Will you find out for me what, if anything, is the worth of some bound copies of Harper's Weekly, from July to December, 1898. I suppose there are a lot around, but these issues have some wonderfully matter-of-fact accounts of the Spanish-American War.
Reading them gave me the strangest feeling, like living in someone else's nightmare.
- Is [Budric?] still impeding the flow of the nation's life-blood, Commerce? Ol'Bottleneck, they call him on the platform[s?]. Blake

Blake,
2635 Commonwealth
Jacksonville, Fla.
This side of card is for address
Jack Conroy,
6012 S. Green St.
Chicago 21,
Ill

Jack, will you please forward to me the address of the Kitten Club on South State? I would ask La Belle, but she is off on some feverish fandango of her own, and not to be found. What's with Lorenzo the Mag? I haven't heard from him since he sent me a copy of Ebony magazine, for [?] devious reason which I think I shall leave un-probed.
Jim Blake.

Jan. 13, 1953.
Dear Nelson,
A few spitballs from a disorderly kitchen. See what you think.
What do you think of the 49,000 missing militarists who went over the fence? Ah youth, insouciant, insurgent! There is yet hope.
Ever,
Blake.
Box 31,
Oconomowoc, Wis.
P.S. The thing about the Bedevilled Baptists is coming, but slow.
P.P.S. Received your letter just as I was about to mail this. About payment from La Prensa, I am indifferent and again, I am not. Not, because of the cost of my present post-moonpause affair is soaring (how do they learn so goddam fast?). But it was gratifying, in a weird way, to have them published at all, and it was a kind of thin-end-of-the-wedge, perhaps. But the failure to send me even a copy of the thing or to answer my letter, even as hobbledehoy as it was, seemed a shade contemptuous. de Beauvoir ma y be busy, but I wrote to Doris Day and got an answer and a picture, too.
Your relegating of the Shores of Light reminds me that I have not yet re-read The Golden Arm. But for a different reason. I think I am afraid to find out how inept I really am in the business of words.
The news about Paris is dismaying. Whatever will I do for guidance? As for Julius and Ethel, I wish you would stay out of those loaded issues. Easier to defeat by deceit than hollering. over

April 6, 1953
Dear Jack,
I've been afraid to write to you, full of a guilty knowledge that I lost your Ronald Firbank. But I have been after Nedwick for a replacement, and it will yet reappear.
Been on the rack, suffering what authors are supposed to suffer. K. McCarthy, out of Doubleday by Crosstown Bus, says "The sufferings of a real writer," "We may have an unique human-experience here." Onnastagahd! Lew-eez-eeanna!
People should get out of New York once in a while. I've been reading the Selected Prose of Bernard Shaw and ran across this in The Education of An Actress. "Adrian Herbert say daily in his studio, painting a companion picture to the Lady of Shalott, and taking less exercise than was good either for himself or his work." I went out forthwith, and bought a bicycle, and exhausted myself on the surrounding hills. Nothing perceptible happened.
Recently, I've enjoyed Huxley's Devils of Loudun, a very pointed affair if anybody wants to make something of it, and have also enjoyed Nicholas Monsaarat's peevish critique of Herman Wouk.
Peachy, I hope they kill one another in the water, while the boat goes down.
ever,
Jim
Box 31, Oconomowoc, Wis.

June 13, 1952
Dear Jack -
I am really a graceless ungrateful lout for not having written sooner to thank you for the week I spent at your house. Nothing could have been more enjoyable and relaxing. There should be more house parties like that, where the host gathers his guests together, shows them where the food is, where the toilet is, and then goes off on an excursion of his own.
Thus, everyone can have as fine or as dull a time as he likes. The host, returning, has only two worries. a.) will they still be there? b.) will the house still be there?
This is wild and beautiful country up here, great booming forested hills jutting up all around, loud brooks tumbling through rocky chasms, and at night the clear demented incessant cry of the whipoorwill.
Beetown was founded in 1832 when extensive lead deposits were discovered in the hills - after a short and turbulent time as a mining town, the lead gave out, and the place sank into sommolence, the violence and rapacity of the pioneers a rueful memory. But the ghosts are still in the hills and the sense of history is strong here. It was through these hills
(over)

-2-
that the French fur traders traveled to Prarie du Chien, then an Indian metropolis - and twelve miles away on the Mississippi is the old, once-hectic river town of Cassville. But I have just begun to delve into the rather wistful history of the region and I know very little about it as yet.
A modern note - There is extensive dairy farming in this territory. One of the familiars hereabouts is a guy who goes about artificially inseminating cows with a plastic phallic device. The kids, with a charming candor, call him "The Cow-Fucker," and bawl the name of him whenever he passes.
I have been re-reading "Antic Hay," a novel of the period that you (and I) so esteem. What a bitterly savagely funny book it is! [Gambril?] and his pneumatic trousers with the inflatable seat (for church pews) Myra [Unveash?] and her passions for the advertising signs in Picadilly Circus - ("Hop, twitch, flick - yes, genuinely an illusion of jollity there, Theodore. Genuinely.") And all the others. If you are [bowed?] down by reading too many lugubrious modern soul-[serapings?], Huxley is as airy as a balloon ascension.
We are doing very little drinking or carousing up here, being too busy (and too broke, in very truth) to take time out for hangovers. Nature is a kind but exacting master and any interruption in the rhythm of growing things

-3-
seems to take its toll. But I find it a good feeling to be tired after a day of physical exertion, and to follow the brook up a rocky defile to where there is a small waterfall and pool deep in the woods. There I strip and plunge into the stinging cold water, to emerge glowing refreshed and invigorated.
This simple regimen is doing considerable to give me peace of mind. I still have my unguarded moments when all my little neuroses cluster about my knees like small whey-faced [stavelings?], their round eyes peering anxiously up at me, mute, intent. What can I tell them, what is it they expect to hear? I shall have to find this cabalistic sign that will set them at rest, poor motherless darlings.
I wonder, Giacomo, if you will take the time and trouble to tie up that box of clothes I left there and send it to me? Before long, I shall be going to work up here, and will be in need of them. I should be ever so grateful, and when I come next to Chicago, I shall bring you some seeds of Chinese wool-flowers.
May your days be sweet, and your impulses flowers.
Sincerely,
Blake
c/o Burns
Box 56
Beetown, Wis.
P.S. I count the world and Lowell Thomas well lost in this retreat, but there must be some things I should know about. Please Write. JB
(over)

Dear Bud - 
Thank you, [Budries?]. You are too good, and I am a yammering ass. One of these vintage days I will get straight and be a stolid citizen. When I see you, I shall have some pot which beats anything I've had in years. Talk about twist your mind, it puts your cortex right out of business. Jenny and Ken have asked me to extend an invitation to Jack and you whenever you want to come. I think you would find it worth the trip. Get on wheels, lad.
A toi,
Blake

July 4, 1952.
Dear Jack - 
It is a quiet afternoon on July Fourth here in the valley, deep in the hills and I am counting the world well lost, with its frantic pursuits. I have spread a blanket on the lawn beneath the trees, and all is calm somnolent peace.
In this atmosphere, it is quite a stretch to recall the rollicking depravity and duplicity of the gentlemen I knew on the chain gang and whose amiable savagery I am trying to put into a novel about my Dixie misadventures.
I suggested hopefully to Nelson that I might be sent to North Africa to fester creatively with Truman (Capote, not Harry) Paul Howles and the other malign spirits. Some dark brews seem to come out of that country and that confluence.
Whatever comes of this effort - and I find it is an effort to communicate what I feel through the comparatively rigid medium of words after the luxury of being as cloudy and enigmatic as I pleased in music - I shall chew away at it until I have told my tale. The awful compulsion will give me no rest.
Last night, the young and prosperous farmer for whom I have been working a little took me out and got me drunk. - But that story really begins with Rimbaud. I was reading "A Season in Hell" about a week ago and came
(over)

-2-
across these words. - "Enter anywhere, answer to anything! They can no more kill you than if you were a corpse!"
Well! That seemed an excellent and provocative attitude to take. And fraught with intriguing possibilities, especially for one as cursed with timidity as I am.
Accordingly, when this farmer called a few days later, looking for somebody to help bale and load hay, I volunteered, though I had to tell him I hadn't the foggiest notion of what had to be done.
I soon found out that my chain gang exertions were not entirely in vain. The bales of hay were five feet long and two feet high, weighing about fifty pounds, and had to be lifted from the field where they were dropped by the baler and swung onto a slowly moving wagon. Strenuous work.
But I stayed with it. The farmer, who had been dubious, congratulated me on my work. (We put up about 700 bales).
So I was able to pay Jenny some money towards my keep, and had the considerable satisfaction of meeting one of these cow-struck lads on his own grounds.
Apparently, I interested the farmer. (I had told him of the Florida stretch I did, for the simple amusement that shocking him afforded me.) Last night, he came up and invited me to go drinking. It may be that he merely likes my company, but that explanation is rather too simple for me, and I reject it categorically. My thought is that he wanted to get me drunk

-3-
and extract from me lurid information of some sort. He started out in that direction.
Alas, the whiskey and his own store of guilty secrets were too much for him. He ended up telling me how he had tried to kill his tyrannical father when he, the son, was only seventeen. And there were tearful protestations of filial love and respect for the long-gone parent, who survived to die less spectacularly, in a bed.
Quite an evening.
Thank you for the Listeners and the two bucks. Both were very welcome and much appreciated. The Pritchett story was a gem (what a deft and astute fellow he is!) The bit about 
Margaret the barmaid - "Her black hair looked as if it had belonged to a former employer" - Inspired. Somehow I must get his "Mr. Belumele."
The whole content and attitude of the magazine suggests once again that the British, whatever their present financial difficulties, are doing the kind of thinking which is and will continue increasingly to be required in the war of ideas. May they flourish.
If you care to send any other British magazines, I should be glad to get them. Kenneth, the painter who lives here and is a sympathetic and sensitive soul, was also intrigued and would like to know more of what is going on over there.
As ever,
Blake.
c/o Burns.
Box 56
Beetown, Wis.

Sept. 12, 1952.
Dear Jack -
[Idle?] to say that I am ashamed of waiting so long to thank you for your thoughtful and interesting letter, and for the Listeners and the copies of Gambit. The latter has a fresh young brash and angry approach, but it also achieves a terrifying sophistication in its dealings with subjects esoteric. Some of it left me quite abashed, feeling that my feet were too long and my socks mismated.
The book you sent, Evening [Heron?], has me puzzled and pretty thoroughly backed off, so far - I've tried, three times, to finish it, but no. All I can think of is Les Precreuses Ridicules, for some reason. I need more time, or some other kind of mental equipment.
For Father Hemingway's new novella (chic!) I need only a box which I can mount, displaying my ignorance for the world to see. Brendon Gill, in the N.Y.'er, says we must be ever so careful not to call it a parable about fishes, which would diminish it. [Parblew?]! I had already labeled it such, and bracketed it with the original fish story (the one with the loaves) and too soon had I come to the conclusion that both of them left me partially appeased, but still hungry.
I read it in the Walgreen edition, and then read in Time magazine some such quote as this - "Isn't it a strange damn story that it should affect us all (especially me) so much?" From Mr. H. - Rather than, "Is it not a strange and wonderful thing that I should earn 30,000 bucks as easily as this?"

-2-
As a person trying to write, I would say it is a dazzling job, easy and liquid prose, everything clicks. It is a good job, however dull.
As a reader who thinks about what he reads, and tries to gain something from it, I would say it is a fraud. "Write truly," Mr. H. has said. What Cuban fisherman calls the fish he catches for a livelihood "my brother?" (But do not call it a parable.) It is a parable, the shabby and obvious kind that appears daily in political cartoons (or is that allegory?) with everything nearly labeled, "Greed," "Hate," "Gov. Corruption."
And oh, the "Humility" of it! Can anyone write of humility (it is a thing, when you are cursed with it, that you do not parade, - or perhaps it is a thing born in you, like a bald head, you have it, but the discovery of it comes as a not completely happy surprise) who is so brassily arrogant? If it is so, it is a miracle of projection.
Finally, what the hell is the good of the language if we are down to 4-letter words? What follows, 3-letter ones? The monotonous pedestrianism, the self-conscious simplicity of that kind of writing (and reading, [boss?]) will have us all back to simple ejaculations like "Arp!"
I've just finished G.B. Stern's "Woman in the Hall." It may not be "Great", and his prose weaves and bobs, but, oh, it is an enjoyable experience!
Neck out,
Blake.
(over)
Rogers' Memorial Sanitarium,
Oconomowoc, Wis.

Add: O.K., I am aroused, and I am ashamed of it, cool disinterest, judicial amaze, has always been safer. But I will be everlastingly god-damned if the enemy that everyone faces in this life is as simple and forthright as a shark. I repeat, a* fuckin' fraud!
Joo Boo
The Schizo Kid
Add: "Dull" I called it, which is not quite right - (you see how afraid I am of [lese majeste?]?") Not "dull" but "wrong." He has been too long in the Tropics, let him return to the jungle that is not so simple, the asphalt.
Forgive me all this heaviness, somebody must listen, and everybody here has a built-in defense, total ignorance.
Joo Boo

For "fuckin'" read "bloomin'." Decorum, if naught else.

Oct. 6, 1952
Dear Jack -
Mother always said that if you go around asking for it, sooner or later you'll get it - I rather [querulously?] and rashly complained that Hemingway's language was over-simplified - then I read Steve Feldman in Gambit (the article on Chaplin's "Monsier Verdoux"), and no amount of earnest re-reading will ever make it clear to me, at least the opening paragraphs. Rather tantalizing, like having a can of anchovies and no opener. What makes it worse is that it's so pleasant to find someone, in these leaden and materialist times, who will take the trouble to go on at much length on a subject so recherche. The cause is a worthy one, and the indignation beautiful to behold - so I do wish that the beginning of the article didn't elude me.
- And I don't, to my shame, know what a "periphrasis" is. 
The last paragraph delighted me. Probably it proves that he is a young man writing in a fine young rage, but it need not have been edited at white heat. This is sheer niggling, but I can't resist it - I quote: 
"Thus it is that, with baited (sic.) breath, we are waiting the advent of a new Chaplin on the American screen."
- Better to keep a clear head, if we've got a fight on our hands, wouldn't you say?

-2-
Oh well, - the joke is undoubtedly as small and weak and private as the hiccup of an oyster - throw it out.
I'm still hard at the business of being a solid and constructive citizen, working like a demon - but more and more possessed by the uneasy suspicion that I've been tricked, and by my self, yet. I had by no means abandoned the idea of further excursions into crime, with the utter freedom of the "balls-to-all-of-it" stand such a pursuit affords. But the idea of this works intrigued me, and now I find the lost ones depending upon me to a dismaying extent. I find too, that I love them. Trapped, by God!
Now my plans for living outside society and finding freedom-in-jail will have to wait, perhaps forever. Because something like this (or any detestable "good-works") robs one of the holy dedication and high moral purpose one needs in the pursuit of crime.
The story of Wendell Wilcox is excellent, I think. There is a sharply cruel quality to his insight, makes one a little uncomfortable, he is so pitiless and acute.
The Gambit review on Eugene O'Neill (by Paul Kolers) is certainly an addled bit, my opinion. Mr. K. says, "But our present preoccupation is growth; construction is in the air."
It is indeed. That hammering sound he hears is man constructing a gallows for himself.
Ever,
Blake
Rogers Memorial Sanitarium
Oconomowoc, Wis.

Oct. 17, 1952
Dear Jack -
This is what I was trying to say about Hemingway - it's by Anthony West in the N.Y.'er: "Compared with the evil that sits smiling in the family group or mingles with the guests at a wedding in a neat suit, the evil that hides behind shutters in a red-light district is neither very deadly nor very interesting" (I presume the little petulant loss of the head at the end there, "nor very interesting," is to let us know that Mr. West is a jaded sophisticate, but he is an astute critic, I think. Anyway he says what I wanted to say, that evil is not as simple as a shark.
Incidentally, they say that Zanuck is doing the Hemingway book for the movies. They're changing the title, calling it "My Brother's Kipper."
One of the patients here is the delight of my life, Godfrey Lovett his name is, a former Field's buyer, who has put it all down and is now sitting on the sidelines making remarks. "Hurry hurry hurry keep up with the race, have a good time g'by," he says. Sunday he had a spirited row with the television set. He had been sitting close to the set, giving it a moody eye when the announcer started one of those

-2-
belaboring feverish commercials - Godfrey listened while the announcer worked himself to a pitch, leaned forward and said in a tone of elaborate solicitude "Don't try to do too much!"
He got up and left the room, giving the set a quick glare over his shoulder, kicking his foot back at it.
When he came back, there was a Western on, and a young woman was berating, at length, a cowboy on a horse. Godfrey watched her for a while, her shrill voice continuing its tirade. Then he leaned forward and looked deep into the screen, said menacingly "I told you to shut your mouth ten minutes early."
It ended in something of an uproar, with Godfrey shouting at a band of fleeing riders "Stop that shooting, I said!" So I shut the thing off. He was content, and returned to an earlier conversation he'd been having with somebody in a department store, with an air of where-were-we-now.
Up the rebels,
Blake.
Rogers Memorial San.
Oconomowoc, Wis.

Oct. 24, 1952
Dear Bud-
You're wonderful, man. Now I have all the ingredients for euphoria. I shall get up on a very high shelf and think about aspects and attitudes.
The product is certainly a great thing to have around, particularly since I have encountered for the first time the middle-class in the people I work with. I used to see them around, these people, gaping at me over a bar as I played my sad pale little piano. They seemed to be an aggressive pushy-type people, so I avoided knowing them as much as possible and moved happily in a jangling little group of deviates of one kind or another.
I've made the jolting discovery that the people who are called the core of the nation are stupid and malicious beyond belief, sluggish and [bound?] and possessed of a strange and easily wounded pride. They communicate with one another in an idiot babble of clichés and cant. The backbone of the nation
(over)

-2-
is caterpillar-soft, Doctor. Do you think we're ready for the Bear?
[Kimian?] sounds a shade querulous these days. She's doing in New Orleans what she did on W. Madison, angling in some dime-lit deadfall, which always has a tendency to jiggle her focus, with the result that she comes on which an air of general banditry to friends and foes alike.
In a recent letter she gave Maurie too much credit. He never had such material to work with.
I've decided to stay with this thing through the winter, both for loot and because I want to learn it thoroughly. But this positive or head-on approach as a way of life is eventually not for me. I want something with a little more slant, and I like to operate out of a crouch. I've got an idea that this kind of job would make a wonderful front for maneuvering around in down in dear old Dixie.
What I mean is I want a re-match.
Yrs.,
BL
P.S. I forgot to say that I'll definitely be in Chicago Nov. 3 for a couple of days
Be wonderful to see you, astringent one. Shall we foregather?

Oct. 26, 1952
Dear Bud -
You might easily consider this an imposition and a lousy nerve and if you do, just skip it - but I would so much like to have some bennies on hand when I do my next night duty, three nights beginning Friday 31.
The others, I needn't tell you, were received with glad cries, and were a great help to me in finishing a couple of songs I've been working on with a view to submitting them to Phyllis, Page's carbonated sister.
I shared the goodies with my boy, of course, and he was galvanized, chattering like a chipmunk, a nice change from his intimidating moroseness. It's rather important for me to keep him happy and as is.
Night duty affords me the only real opportunity I get for my attempts at writing, and I require some scientific assistance in keeping awake for it.
What can I do in return? Anything short of sponsoring you for the American Legion. I have a quantity of phenobarb, amassed through cunning and stealth, and will gladly send it to you if you want it.
(over)

-2-
I'm hoping that you'll be around for the few days I'll have in Chicago from Nov. 3. That paradoxical attitude, the mixture of patrician fastidiousness and calculated outrage that is uniquely yours, has always been a thing to marvel and wonder at, and I should like another long look, if I may.
In constancy,
Blake.
Box 31,
Oconomowoc, Wis.

If you should decide to make the trip, make it the week-end or the beginning of the week. Those days I am free.
Tomorrow, we get a new patient, a young Catholic priest who tried to drown himself. God, I hope he's ugly. Otherwise.
Hester Prynne,
Rides again.
Dobie

Sep 9.53.
Dear Bud,
Thank you, father, for the bon-bons. Employed with a measure of restraint, they will help to flog my flagging cortex into action. The sad sack saga moves slowly, mostly sidewise; surrounded by bears as I am, I grow slightly bearish, and trying to create something stabbingly beautiful for the ages requires a lot of projection.
Clearly, you do not listen when I speak. Some day I may say something, and you will be sorry. It will take anyway half a yard to move the farmer off the farm, probably six bits, as I mentioned. Having had to pay for the porcelain facade, I'm souped financially, and can't advance it. And being on my last month in this job, it's difficult to raise any loot. Think os something, querido, and let me know, and I'll contact the farmer.
Bamboo is a black-hearted black man in Milwaukee, an excellent fellow for an erotic tussle, subversive on sacred things like white supremacy, with an IBM for a brain.
Wonderful idea, to get the incandescent Algren off the Calumet for a trip to Wisconsin. If to Milwaukee, why not here, thirty miles more? I'll arrange for a free shock-treatment on the house, for all.
The golden bear, bane and glory, has gone on ahead to Fla. The chill in the air frightened him, giving him premonitions of being hit by a glacier. So I've lost my ride, but it's better thus, only spasmodically can I exercise any control over him, and we'd probably have wound up in Brushy Mountain, diggin' and dyin' for the commonwealth. I'm meeting him in Jax, and hoping I will have the strength to leave him there.
The Sandiford boy is really down. Sincere, a little over-earnest, but withal quite a something, I think. Toujours, Jim
What's with this "Julius" noise? Ne comprends pas.

Oct. 25.53.
Dear Nelson - 
Thank you for the lift. It will enable me to maintain the proper financial relations with the sly Pat sach of evil who runs this charmed house. This thing unfolds as it goes along, quite interestingly - The head nurse is a West Virginia girl, muscled and athletic, looks like a whore somehow, who starts the day by reading aloud to the assembled workers from a book called "My Lord and I." Then the Assistant Head says a prayer. She is a drab sexless girl of uncertain age, with long teeth and muddy hair and skin. After this grisly rite, which leaves them close to tears, they begin to scatter demerol around the joint like it was fly spray.
They have one villa here that is occupied exclusively by shattered play-boys, who stay knocked out all the time on one thing or another. O the wonders of the pharmacoepia.
Tell David that his horticultural effort has been my staff and my rod in this time of trial. I stroll after work by the bayou and turn it on, and all is suddenly afloat. My congratulations to David. Perhaps you'd better show him that Gary Post-Tribune, before he gets any ideas.
I won't have anything bad said about V. [Bourjaille?]. He likes my stuff, he must know what he's about. Consider, though, Gilbert Highet and his petulant attack on Andre Gide. Highet has been touted as the greatest, but in the Gide article, he sounds like Woollcott with religion. (over)

Speaking of Calder Willingham, "End As A Man" has [??ded] as a play, and if they got a play out of that novel - I think "Golden Arm" could be a shattering play, with the right incidental music to compliment the dialogue. I don't mean an opera, just little touches - I know just the boy who could write it, Paul [??dow]. Know the man for the dialogue, too - he lives behind a dune, in a little crouching house, with a wee, wee wife and a little brown mouse.
Thank you again, Pappy, it will return. About the work, tomorrow I'm going out and find a quiet stretch of sand at Maderia Beach, and work at it all day.
One word, and then no more. Your analysis of my problem is good, but wrong. It does take up too much time, that's what annoys me. I shall try to rectify it.
What's from Lawrence?
En [avant?]
Jim
Bayou Saw
4151 4th St. South,
St Peter

3W, Pinellas County Jail
Clearwater, Fla.
Jan. 28. 54.
Dear Jack - 
Seems I only write to you from the Cage, but I had to tell you how much I enjoyed your bastille boubaillaise, not the lease of which was 'Eleanor in the Nether-World.' "Repetitious," I believe was her comment, in part. Eleanor was ever a word-mincer. But no, that is snide, I withdraw it.
Not long ago (while I was still Out There) I ran across your holy name in a foreward to Nathanael West's Day of the Locust. The book was somewhat disappointing to me and I never finished it. Some rough seas were running at the time in my own disorderly existence, however, and it may have been my state of mind. However I did think that the scene in which the hill collapsed under a mock-charge during the making of the historical movie was immense, and very very funny. I'll go back to it one day. One distant day, alas, if the fates persist in booting my country ass around.
The good gray Dr. A has intimated that my latest storming of the Bastille was part of some devious design. The kid's positively eerie. At one time there was in a dim recess of my mind the urge for a flight-into-custody, but the responsibility of caring for all the lost little loons in mental hospitals made it necessary to discard the selfish impulse. I felt that I was in a battle I couldn't decently walk away from. Now I seem to be benched whether I would or no.

-2-
The opus is coming slowly, knowing so little about the mysteries of the craft, I must grope my way along. And working under present conditions is like trying to lay a mosaic in a revolving door.
I hope you got your Firbank from Nelson. I know how you prized it - as indeed would I, he is a strange and bewitched genius.
If you have any English magazines you'd care to send, they'd be [unldly?] welcome. Nothing to read hereabouts but those literary carbuncles delicately known as 'f__k-books.'
ever,
Jim
P.S. Forgot to say that the Doubleday verdict on the 50 pp. I submitted was 'terribly intrigued.' But not, apparently, sufficiently ensnared to write a contract. Makes it my move, I guess.

W. Pinellas County Jail.
Clearwater, Fla.
Jan. 28. 54.
Dear Bud,
The oracle of Delphi-on-the Dunes was pissed, sure enough. I had a letter intimating that I had made a *flight-into-custody of my own volition. The boy is brilliant and it was a shrewd cast, but wrong. I'll own that it was in the back of my mind at one time, but after I became busy and comparatively content, I discarded it. Then Kismet stepped in and walloped me. That's what I get for harboring off-brand impulses.
First reaction was dismay, but it's past, you can't stay dismayed very long, not and operate. I'm sweating out that contract, and trying to write under adverse conditions. The boys are a happy band of extroverts and concentration is difficult.
But it marches, my brave. Doubleday they say "terribly intrigued" by what they've seen thus far, but they're still coy. I'm on the rack, Dad.
Ol' Jack is a real stylish person, [??t] and scholar, his college was a boat.
And Victor Bernstein's words were music. ButI wish they'd send me shosies, posies I don't need.
ever,
Jim
P.S. Ain't seen any magazine.
[Doep] sent a smashing lot of paper. Stout fellow.
'Ware the Equine!

Feb. 16. 54
Dear Jack - 
Either the letter I sent you went awry or you have been too busy to reply. I cannot believe you could be indifferent to my pitiful plight. ("It is nothing to ye, all ye who pass by?") Your jailhouse pastiche, which I got via Fallow, was most amusing, also heartening - I find myself quoting Donne on the subject frequently. And the outraged Dickens.
I am still chewing out my own vitals in the process of excreting a masterpiece - to make the metaphor woolier, I feel like a slug on a vast, endless cabbage leaf - Gnaw, gnaw, gnaw, with no discernible progress.
Until recently, I was trying to work in a tank with about fourteen other guys, and concentration was the least, to say the most. I took my problem to the Captain, and he gave me a cell by myself. So now I'm locked in with the Thing, and there is nothing to do but work. I remember reading recently that somebody offered James Jones eight-million dollars, or some such sum, to appear on television and he said he was too busy working on his second book, that he was "living with his characters." Man, he's nowhere, I'm locked up with mine.
How did you like the Warren book? I note that Eleanor, the word-mincer, found it 'repetitious.' It was a trifle solemn, perhaps, but there appears to be some sort of ferment there.
Remember to lower the flag Thursday the 18, and beat the drum slowly. Got any Limey magazines? Ever, Jim
Aren't these the gray days for the loose-living, lily-livered Liberals? How fares the College of Ku Kluxes?

May 23.54.
Dear Lorraine,
Been sweating out a letter from you for two weeks, sister mine, where are you, shy [waler?]? Hope you didn't mind my requesting a pair of sun-glasses, but there really is a necessity - especially when the band plays at the ball games, we're out in the sunlight, and I've been getting headaches from the glare.
From the literary front - The Agent has moved the little orphan over to the front stoop of [Valeing?], in the hope that Malcolm Cowley will take it in. No word yet. The next issue of the prison magazine Raiford Record will, I am told, contain a story by one "Blake." Will forward a copy when it comes out shortly. Also, have done a short story the Mule in the Pool, and attempt at commercial comedy, which I'm submitting with some trepidation to Amanda's husband, in the trembling hope he will judge it gently for what it is, a money-trap to snare some of that free-world loot.
On that point, I wonder if you could advance me a [fin?] on my prospects. I hate to give you this loot-shot all the time, but it's fairly urgent that I clear up my dates here. The guys here are all fare, ['yummerstan'?], but it ain't exactly Scout Troop 8, in addition to which, in a small tight microcosm of society like this, it's unwise (and inconvenient) to be known as a poor credit risk. If you will, you real satin doll? July 16. 54.
Dear Lorraine,
I keep firing these things out into the wild blue, and nothing keeps happening. What is it with you? May I hear, coy wahn?
I'd like to give you a picture of the joint, if I may. Physical layout, that is. Raiford is, I believe, the only pen surrounded by fence instead of walls. Three fences, two of them about ten feet high, between them one about sixteen feet high, charged at the top. Entirely adequate for the purpose, you will agree, but avoiding the claustrophobic pall that a wall imparts.
Within the fences, a busy compound, - no expanses of concrete, rather wide stretches of grass, dominated by the long three-story E-shaped main building, a blinding dazzle of white in the Florida sun. The inner courts between the wings are planted with Washington palms and other tropical flora. Another huge white building opposite houses the mess-hall and the auditorium, where movies are shown Sunday nights, with the orchestra playing before and after.
A paved street runs down the center, leading to the various work-plants (one which makes the state license-tags) - there is a chapel, recently built, red-brick and admirably restrained in architecture, the interior of which is the exposed brick and glowing cedar, the windows amber glass -

Blake 52603-3dF&T
-2-
a quiet serene place, blessed refuge from the hurly-burly of the 'Rocks.' Across from this, the visitor's park, dotted with quaint open pavillions, rather like an English resort, where the military band (in which I play dogmatic, downright bass drum) plays every day at noon.
Such then is my home, and like a skeptical house cat in new quarters, I still experience some small differenlty in settling in. To that end, I'm attempting to get into a two-man cell, where I'll be able to continue work on the book. That entails a certain amount of what made the mare go, but I'll not bug you with it. I miss your letters very much, it is ineffably dreary not getting mail.
I've written Doef Loeb the law-man in an effort to enlist his aid in collecting some money due me from my rap-partner, who went off once again to the luxury of Jax. Presuming to a degree, I know, but needs must when necessity knocks.
It's ironic that I'll probably leave here a better musician than I came, when as far as the music racket goes, I've had it.
Regards to Bud, the warmest, and a nod to his equine friends. Now please, pause in your mad pursuits, sister mine, to lay a line on me.
Heard from Gert and Paul about Conroy's now. Deeply regrettable - Jack is so rare and radiant a spirit.
ever,
Jim

Sept. 29. 54.
Dear Lorraine,
These are the days of coolness and mist in the mornings, of sunlight filtered through the autumn haze, massive brooding clouds piling into towering shapes, bursting in splenetic downpours towards evening. Prelude to the short, damp and penetrating winter of North Florida. No hurricanes yet, but one keeps hoping.
Thank you for the loot, it was most opportune, and I was able to make good use of it. I've been working on some tunes which I hope to sell to Mabel Mercer, the New York 'chi-chi' chanteuse-torch-song stuff, written in an effort to ease my recent bereavement, but also with a view to making myself self-supporting in some degree.
You may have heard that Paul Warren has finished the first draft of another book, a sequel to 'Next Time for Life.' I envy the boy's facility and drive, my work goes so inchingly slow, two pages in a day being phenomenal. Not that I expect to have any 'Karamazoo' at the end of it, but I feel the necessity of trying for absolute honesty. Struggling for clarity in the picture, while attempting to find the line between cliché and monkey-cleverness - all this, with a mind sketchily educated, and veiled recurringly in loneliness and the shadow of despondency - it is a challenging task. Alors, one must pursue something, if only a chimera.
I've been hung up for some time on a section which must be done convincingly and with finesse, if it is not to collapse into

-2-
triviality - only thing, I'm nagged constantly by the haunting suspicion that Nelson's scalpel will deal with it in one swift clean operation. Why I'm burdening you with all this I don't know, unless because I'm tired of telling it to myself. Redoubled effort is perhaps the best cure for the vapors.
I've added another duty to my endeavors here, that of playing for the colored chain rehearsals and their Sunday services in the prison chapel. That is, it was a duty when I first took it on, but I am finding it increasingly a distinct pleasure. Their simplicity and directness are a bracing breeze after my daily contacts with the familiar transparent chicanery and spiritual bankruptcy of my Caucasian compatriots. And the a cappella singing of both the men's and women's choirs on Sunday are a wonder of pulsing warmth and musical inventiveness, really a delight to hear.
Already I am looking forward to your visit in the late fall or early winter. I hope you will be able to make it - you must let me know in good time so that I can arrange a visitor's pass for you. Till then, hearing from you is the next best.
ever,
Jim

Dear Lorrraine,
Thanks ever so much for the welcome loot, babydoll. I'm keeping track of it, and come the day when I'm able to sell the yard of tripe I'm working on, I'll be able to partially repay you-for the kindness I shall have to be ever in your debt. 
Things rock along here and placid monotony, on e day being like another for the most part-there are minor excitements and sensations, an astounding amount of gossip, and a certain measure of harmless intrigue (like a Ferris Wheel it starts nowhere, goes nowhere, arrives nowhere, but everyone is mildly titillated by the ride). 
My musical duties have settled down to routine, requiring not too great of an effort, leaving me time and energy to pursue small projects of my own, like a couple of times I'm working on in the hope of peddling them thanks to Mabel Mercer, the New York chartreuse who specializes in singing those Love-Is-A-Pain type of songs. I've finished one tune (though I'm letting it cool for awhile, better to be able to tell if it's anywhere), a very simple waltz (in the confusion that obtains everywhere nowadays, I think it possible that the waltz may come back also it is a form that permits simplicity in lyrics)

-2-

Simple, that is, musically-I've tried for a deceptive, devious, sort of simplicity in the lyrics, expressing a nostalgic yearning for a certain New York afternoon when the rain was falling outdoors while indoors firelight flickered, Debussy murmured seductively from the phonograph and hanky-panky was rife. It's called, suitably enough Rainy Afternoon in Town. (Afternoons, rainy ones in particular, have always seemed to me the best time for entanglements-the world is far away, in offices and bus depots, and eroticism is heightened- and then, afterwards one can always take the adversary out for something to eat and over a Martini or bowl of borscht measure the immediate extent of one's depredations.  Best to have these things clear-cut--where a period of slumber intervenes, wooliness sets in, defenses are repaired, the old evasions return. 
I'm still asking everyone I know is there any chance for a radio--

Nov 6, 54 
Dear Lorraine, From Gertrude and Paul I hear that you were briefly in Chicago, and intended to winter again in Florida. Now's as good a time as any to start beseeching you to detour a little and visit me. It would be a memorable change for me, to see some faces from outer space; my relations with my fellow penitents are pleasant enough, but the same visages (with the same messages: day on day eventually pall, and the meetings and exchanges of convicts become as ritualistic and predictable as a Kabuki play the tenth time around.
Also, I assume that a visit to this unusual-type joint might be of interest to you. You will hear our concert brass band, which plays in the visitor's park daily-one of the unusual features of Raiford is the visiting system. No wire mesh between me and my loved ones, rather a pleasant little pavilion where one may spread an al fresco lunch amid nodding palms. Such an arrangement presumes, of course, that you will not come loaded down with hacksaws, bombs, and booze. Easy does it, chéri. 

 You will also see how sleek and contented I am, living my calm monastic existence with my music, my books, and my geraniums, the world well lost. Along that line, I'm eligible for parole the 18th of this month. I've asked the Warrens, since they live near him, to ask Dolf Loeb if he would care to help me in this matter. It may not be so, but I have an idea that letters pertaining to parole receive perhaps quicker attention from the parole board if they come from a lawyer. Perhaps it's too much of an imposition, though, and if necessary I can probably handle

it myself necessary to have a job to go to, however, and on that I'm afraid I'll need assistance. I'm going to try for an out of state parole to Illinois, having reached the conclusions that Florida and I are incompatible. I've settled into what may be my permanent quarters during my stay here, a two-man cell which I share with a burly lad from Syracuse doing twenty for armed robbery. He's a pleasant uncomplicated type who writes doughty, solemn poetry (some of which I have set to pale, absent-minded music) and Western stories in which the cardinal virtues are enthroned, a horse is a 'critter' and the bad guys are transparent stinkers from page one. 

  What amazes me about this exile from society and many others I've encountered here, is that most of the copy-book maxims of their childhood are still as Holy Writ to them. Ideas, standards, prejudices that form the foundations of society, which were pounded into them from infancy are still there, intact, uncontested, unexamined. (Except for the one about property, which has been altered to All Property Is Theft" or perhaps it's vice versa). How then, and why, did they fall from conformity? It's a nice puzzle to gnaw on. 
  I'm told that magazines like the N. Y'er and such may be received if mailed in a magazine mailer with the address type or printed, one of each type weekly. Care to test it? I miss the NY'er sorely. Only if you can do so without great inconveniences. 
  The opus is still opus-ing. Gad, I'll be glad to see the last of the pesky thing, to get on to something lighter.

love,
Jim
P. S,  Advise about the visit?

Dear Lorraine,

   The note of wistful nostalgia in your last letter touched and distressed me.  For some reason, (and it has always been thus) my own mild and chronic unease bothers me less than the thought that you should be unhappy.  You've always been, at least to me, a person of vast reserve and taciturnity, and if you ever chose to show any degree of emotion, it always seemed to me a studied parody of what you were really feeling - only when you were gay did the mood seem to ring true, it would have been impossible to simulate the bubbling delight you felt.  Perhaps it seemed so rich because it was so rare.  So much of  you has always  been in a minor key.  So much careful darkness that the flashes of light were revelations - ah well,  as always when I try to say what I deeply feel, I flounder.  Besides, I was never permitted truly to know you, and the accrued curiosity has become mountainous.  Some day perhaps I shall be allowed to prospect your psyche, sinking shafts to see what I can strike in that fabulous field.
  But before I get utterly lost in the Outer Imponderables, I want to say that I too have occasionally thought back to those purple days and crimson nights in Chicago - not with nostalgia, but with a sense of awe and wonder that it didn't kill us all.  Law, such excesses, and blind fevered excursions into nowhere.  Many laughs, but it was bitter, doomed laughter, and I might have enjoyed every

Blake 52603-E32
-2-
moment of it, had I not been torn with the tears I was shedding inside, and frightened by the growing shadow that was creeping across my mind. It took a crash through the barrier into the never-never land of the chain gang and two years convalescence at hard labor to heal the effects of that stupendous binge and restore my mental health (i.e. crying on the outside, laughing on the inside.)
It is terrible to be afflicted by the dreadful urge to write everything down, to be forever digging between one's toes in search of an ultimate truth, but I do think that such a morbidly merry crew as we were in those days deserves examining and expounding. (I almost said "exposing" All right, exposing) In terms of those three femmes terribles, Kamion, O'Brien and Gwen, (for it seems to me the males involved were but hapless victims,) I should like to tell the tale. That is, when I relieve myself of the Further Confessions of St. Augustine.
Now that I have burdened you with a lot of neurasthenic nonsense, (springing from a tilted metabolism, I wot), to the factual. I should appreciate Conroy's address. If you can possibly visit  me, advise me in advance, so that I can arrange a visitor's pass. Also, if there's any loose loot, it would be vastly appreciated, since I'm in the scratch. Can't elucidate, but it's fairly grim.
I am doing a good bit of church work here, playing the organ for both white and colored (black) services. I have discovered that when I add a heavy tremolo to the background organ music during the Invitational, more people come to pray at the altar rail. The Lord moves in mysterious ways and one does what one can.
love,
Jim

Dear Lorraine,
Gratifying to know you're so close, away from the wintry blasts of St. Louis--and dismaying to think that you didn't fall by the Academy en route. Surely this time South I'll see you? I presume you're staying in Hollywood to be near the ever-lovin' equines. 
Thanks so much for the shoes, my feet were murdering me. The Irisher really has formidable feet. Sometime I'll relate to you a piece of local folklore dealing with large pedal extremities. 
No word from the absent one, giving rise to a creeping apprehension that I'm getting a slow shuck. Not too surprising, all things considered--once free of the web of rhetoric I spin, there is a tendency to revert to tribal traits and taboos. Only a temporary defeat, however. I've put too much of myself into that scenario to hold still for such an unsatisfactory, inconclusive second-act curtain. 
Meanwhile I fulfill my urge to omniscience by giving vocal coaching to a talented and personable young lad who aspired to be a popular singer. In addition, I've discovered the amusing and literate company of a frustrated poet and actor from the Pasadena Playhouse. The combined pursuits partially ameliorate the sting of pique.
The approaching holiday season has prompted a group

Williard?
-2-
of inmate thespians to begin rehearsals for the annual Christmas theatrical, a spectacle paralyzingly ecclesiastical. The mummers are a drably earnest and motley lot, the vehicle suitably innocuous. I've been sounded for the job of furnishing the organ background again, and have demurred--irreverence is too sacred a thing to dissemble, I feel--but I fear I shall end by concurring.
Last year, I found some small diversion in furnishing a leitmotif constructed from vagrant bits of Gershwin's 'Porgy' score--a bracing ammoniacal whiff of breeze in an otherwise airless, moribund affair, it seemed to me. Most poignant, too, it was, I was quite moved. This year, perhaps some of the least detectable bits of Stravinsky would be nice.
Let me hear, booted one.

June 29. 56.
Dear Brid -

    The six days I've been out have been nothing but a hell of anxiety, scrambling and scuffling.   The sawbuck I got at the joint is gone, and the guy who runs the mission here lets me stay in return for working around the joint, but the problem of eating has had to be solved by pilfering from supermarts.  How long I can can [sic] do that without detection is moot.  No loot has gone for lush, I can not only not afford it, but I've got to keep good health in this tight situation.
    Just can't get off the ground with no loot at all, and I dread pulling any jobs and going right back in.   The town's too small for anything fancy.  I've made connections with a couple of local musicians and they're trying to throw a job my way, but until it happens I'm hung up, high.
   I try not to despair, what the hell, I can't, there's too much I want to do - right now, though, it's hard to think of anything but something to eat and a place to stay.
  I'm sorry about the collect call, but I had to try something,  If you can help, and care to, I'll be at the mission - and if I'm forced to move on, I'll leave a Gen Del address wherever I head for.  Rough, baby.

Jim
P.S. Wire if you can.  If nothing at all, I'll understand.  Or try to.
