Duval County Jail   Jacksonville, Fla.
Jan 22.56
Dear Jack,

    Bud recently wrote me a letter from Miami Beach which outboded in dire prophecy the billets-doux that Paul sent to the Ephesians.  Unfortunately, I did not receive it in time, and it was forwarded to me in jail.
  I'm in on charges of breaking & entry and grand larceny.  Seems that taking a hasty rear-exit leave from a ship outfitter's establishment with an armload of binoculars, I collided with an irate policeman.  I now have a faint idea of how it will be when the world ends.
  However, no vain regrets.  I'm looking at a 3 to 5 this trip, from all indications, though there's an outside chance I may get hit with the deck.

-3-

 I intend to make good use of the time, finishing the MS of Chain Dance, and working on another dealing with the Chicago night-club world, an idea that has been kicking around in my head for some time.  
  Paris Review will probably run the Alligator story in the next issue, I'm told.
  I read Dr. A's "Wild Side" before the roof collapsed - found it a delight, raucous, rueful, haunting.  Not the lyric performance of 'Golden Arm', but still formidable.

This is the roughest part of the time, long days of inactivity and idleness, awaiting trial Feb. 19.  If you can send something to read, it would help immeasurably.  And if there's any idle loot around, I could use it to supplement the suicide diet we get here.  Please let me hear.
Ever, Jim Blake

Feb 5.57
Dear Jack -

   Thank you for the ever-lovin' buck, and more so in view of the fact you deprived yourself to send it.  I wish I could be like those accomplished burglars who have buckets of rubies hidden away for just such painful emergencies.   If time doesn't run out on me, I may someday graduate to such eminence and expertise - trouble is that in this school, every wrong answer is screeching disaster.
   I blame it on the Miltown.  Having gulped it injudiciously all Xmas day, I was not only tranquillized but paralyzed.   And filled with such a glacial calm that it is a mercy the banks were closed, I was indomitable and fearless.
   The recklessness was a thing that had been building for some time of course.   The pressures and annoyances of a commercial Yuletide in all its shrill avarice, the frenzy of it, contributed much to the mood.  Even the Salvation Army, always dependable, always a sad and wistful little note in all the garishness, blossomed out in plastic-type shelters and microphones, electronically, deafeningly, beseeching.  Gone were the tripod and kettle, the pleasant small tinkling bell.
   And I wondered what Madison Ave. lout had conceived in his gray-flanneled brain the streamlining of the ancient rite of alms-giving.
   There were other irritations.  The noble art of boosting, always the prime sport of the season, was all but ruined by the crafty ? Dance of these Pharisees.  Ruined, too, by hordes of amateurs.  It got so that one had to tear an article from the competing grasp of some beardless

-2-
infant.  And ordinarily, in Dixie, the hazards of the game are somewhat mitigated by the fact that everybody watches the niggers - (A nigger would sooner steal than eat, ask any Southerner).

  So I'd always figured, they're so busy watching the niggers they won't - but hold! - I thought, I'll bet they got the niggers watching me!  I looked about urbanely, unobtrusively, as I sauntered about the aisle, the picture of a jaded flaneur, a man who shops only for People Who Have Everything.  Sure enough, trailing behind me and about me, a veritable retinue of hired blackamoor spies, hares in the pay of the hounds.   Que voulez-vous, I said, the hell with it.
   So it built up like, as you can judge for yourself.
    I'm looking forward to the magazines, I've been reduced to reading those curiously depressing evangelistic things that rain down on jailbirds on every hand.  If somebody doesn't curb those people, they're going to bring back the Holy Roman Empire and the Pope will be lolling about Miami Beach.
   With your permission, I'd like to put you on my mailing list when I reach the joint.   Your sprightly notes are a delightful tonic.  Incidentally I've been receiving some anonymous postcards from Chicago, sinister things.  I've turned them over to the people who are investigating the kidnaping [sic] of Marie McDonald.  La pauvre Marie, Quel horreur!

ever, Jim
Duval County Jail   Jacksonville Fla

March 2. 57
Dear Jack -

    Thank you for the 'Listeners' and "Cress Delehanty'.  I am always bemused by the gentle, scholarly, amiably bumbling tone of the BBC publication.  It is oddly stimulating even while it is relaxing.  I guess what makes it soothing is the absence of that hell-for-leather insistence on making a point that is so oppressive in American periodicals   Reading the 'Listener', I find myself being gently sprayed with information rather than being belted with it.  There is a charming diffidence throughout, but one does well not to be lulled by it, for fear of missing out on some delicious and bracing literary stabbing.  Ah, the sneaky English.
    The Bowen articles were enjoyable, though I don't think I learned very much.  As far as this method goes, I'm afraid I'm one of the Unteachables, and for me, writing remains an incommunicable disease.
  The good gray Dr. A once gave me, by a seemingly uncanny excising process, an astounding flash of insight into the mystifying craft of writing.  It was a revelation like watching him remove somebody's false whiskers.  Not that in one electrifying moment I understood forever and ever, but at least I glimpsed an important clue.

-2-

  'Cress Delehanty' I thought was overly arch in many spots, though there were some shrewd flashes of wit.   Writers of books about children and adolescents should, I think, remember the words of V. Herbert's song 'Toyland' - "Once you pass its portals, you may never return again."
   In my opinion, the fantasies and fears of youth are so ephemeral, even at their most powerful, that I doubt if many writers are able to recollect them accurately, much less re-live them.  Miss West has skillfully done a character, but it strikes me as more of an airy-fairy than an adolescent.  I abominate airy-fairies.
  Saroyan wrote a story, I think it was called 'The Actress and the Inventor, that came closer to telling what the young are like than anything else I can remember.
  Incidentally, eavesdropping on children at play has always been a favorite pastime of mine - If ever you want a glimpse of the pits of hell and the madness of heaven, I recommend it.
   I go to trial March 5, come hell or high water.  I daresay there will be a sufficiency of both.

Warmest, Jim
Duval County Jail
Jacksonville, Fla

April 16. 57
Dear Bud -

    I drew a ten spot today, and feel somewhat shook about it at present.   The barrister that Lew procured was of very little assistance, I'm afraid.  Just one more card in the pack of cards.   Please tell Jack that I would like to put his name on the mailing list, he has long been my favorite stepfather.  Thus I can bedevil him for books.  Tell him, also, that I was crass about 'Cress'  I'm sorry, I rend my garments in shame and contrition.  The book had charm, and I am a troll, but it was such damnably relentless charm.
   I shall have a pressing need for reassurance that there are people like you in the world, dear Lorenzo, so I hope you will continue to write.
   Later, from the academy.  I leave the 18th

ever, Jim

May 2 . 57
Dear Bud -

   Still no bus for the Academy - this prolonged stay in the Florida counterpart of Newgate has exhausted what loot I was able to save for matriculation fee.
   So I'm reduced to trying to sell the trophies that I brought away from the Battle of Peas Island.  Can you use a gray leather gladstone with a built-in-suit rack?  Practically new, it was given me in the latter days preceding the Disaffection and Downfall, and I used it only on the flight into Fla.
   Ten bucks would be cool, plus express charges to send it from Raiford to you.  I'd have to use it to transport my stuff to the joint, then I'd send it on.   Rather a nice piece I would guess it cost somewhere around $35.  Like to hear soon as possible, the next bus will probably be it.
   Been reading Dostoevski's  House of the Dead and have been mildly exercised to learn that the joint in Siberia is a shade superior to the penal palace in Dixie.  Never thought I'd outdo a Russian in the agony dept.

ever, Jim

Duval County Jail
Jacksonville, Fla

     Well, it's happened.  I was picked up in the park and they found the strom, and now I'm awaiting investigation and disposition of the case. 21st October, 1964
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   Many thanks for sending us a copy of your novel and for the book you sent to Lynne.  I think she must have told everyone in the vicinity that Mr. Conroy sent her a book from America.
   I  have just finished reading "the Disinherited" and thoroughly enjoyed it, but how depressed and guilty it made me feel.  I suppose the times and the hardships of those times, seem twice as bad to a person like myself, who has never experienced hunger, or had no shoes on their feet.  The guilty feeling is caused when I think how easy life has been for me.  Although I have never been spoilt with fancy toys, and anything I just happened to want (and sometimes as a child it was hard to understand just why I couldn't have everything I saw) I can honestly say that life has been

2
comfortable, and never once have I lacked the essentials.  Even now I get discontented when I want both money in the bank besides luxuries, and we have a saying here "You can't have your bun and eat it too".  How true!

    I have been wondering how you got along after the depression, and just how much of your book was fiction and how much was autobiographical.  I read lots of biographies and autobiographies - I suppose I'm just an inquisite person.
   Daddy read  your book and he says it brought back lots of memories of the "lean" years.
   Many thanks once again, and maybe our paths will cross again sometime.  It was a great pleasure meeting you and your wife, and if you are ever in London again, do drop in for the "olde Englishe" custom of tea-drinking.
   Hoping to hear from you again, kindest  regards to you and your wife, from all of us (Mum, Dad, Lynne & Nelson).

Yours sincerely,
?Gary Blessingfield?

October 22, 1956
Dear Conroy,

   Thank you for your note and for Midland Humor, which I am going to delve into afterwhile instead of correcting a dismal set of themes.
   It is, of course, encouraging to learn that a reviewer of our taste and experience enjoyed my treatment of Ridout's [sic] book.   Isn't it strange that a history has to be written about the novels that we were reading only yesterday?   During a part of the period that Rideout covered, I sat at the feet of V. F. Calverton, born George Goetze, who was a left wing sage in my home town.  Rideout mentions him eight or nine times.
   Times have certainly changed and I don't think for the better.   We all eat better, but the food hasn't the old savor.
   I hope that the duplicates of my review that you have sent around help sell some books for Rideout.   I don't know him, but my spies on the Northwestern campus say that he is a good guy.
   I don't know whether our Partridge inspired tape has hit the air waves yet.  I think not, or Al would have let us know.   I made a television appearance for him, talking on the business man in the American novel.  I took the opportunity to deplore the

present trend, but I fear that I reached no great audience at 10:00 A.M. on a Saturday morning.    I did the same sort of thing at a business club luncheon, basing my talk around the about face of Dos Passos, but my audience heard what they wanted to hear.

    I hope that circumstances bring us together soon again.   If you are in the neighborhood of Navy Pier, stop in, and I will shake the beautiful coeds out of my hair and go out for a drink with you.

Cordially,

Resumè
I know that life can be a laugh, a curse,
A probing sigh, a grinding of machines:
An actor sometimes failing to rehearse
And stumbling through his lines in crucial scenes.
And life can also be a ready child,
An old man and a ruffian, so attuned,
And yet so separately soft or wild -
A cross between a blessing and a wound.
And in its clash of poetry and prose,
Idealisms and dishonest frays,
Within bewildering, disturbing ways.
But though it flounders, life has always changed.
A thousand years from now, its mood will be
Increasingly enslaving and deranged, 
Or much more truthful, understanding, free.
One thing is certain - if the human race
Persists in killings, robbings darkly linked,
Mankind will slowly lose its last, faint trace
Of home and finally become extinct.
Maxwell Bodenheim

To Ruth
Yes love, familiar word, can be abused.
It may be only physical desire,
Or fine contentment honestly enthused
Yet barely missing sheer, poetic fire.
My love for you was like a bashful boy
Who entered flames at last, despite alarms.
And then discovered with astonished joy
That he was still intact within your arms! 
And now I still retain my sudden fears,
With thoughts and heart-beats often insecure.
For even though it stands the test of years
Rare loving never dares to be quite sure.
No locks or keys.  Deep love, in growing shape,
Must always feel that it can change, escape!
Maxwell Bodenheim

120
To The Labor Journalism Students
In spite of inexperienced brains and hands,
Your writing holds professional commands.
And equally innate within your hearts,
A search for knowledge lends its tense, clear parts.
Oh yes, I know that you can also be
Impulsive in your dreams, and gayly free,
And that your hearts can sometimes romp and dance
Between adventuring and glistening chance.
But in your studies you are down to earth:
New people ever in a grim re-birth.
And in my stubbornly surviving youth,
I like your ardor and your fight for truth!
Maxwell Bodenheim

Contrasts
Upon these city streets, in deep escapes
Poetic gleams ascend and dreams take shape.
A soldier and a girl, through twining sighs, 
Discover budding souls within their eyes.
Apart from lust, their long embracing finds
Unique surprise in merging hears and minds.
A winsome woman poses in the nude.
The artist's stares are neither sly nor rude.
Impersonal and keen, he lifts each brush
And paints within a sheer esthetic hush.
The building cracks and flames are circling wild.
A man runs in and saves a neighbor's child,
And afterwards, despite the burns and pains,
His twisted smile breaks through them and remains.
This woman, old and frail, scrubs floors for years.
To guard a crippled son from lacks and fears.
Ignoring Home Relief.  Mistaken pride?
[over]

(2) (Contrasts)
Of course, yet courage nestles at her side.
The heroes, poets, are not always those
Who gain the limelights of admiring prose.
No, they are often plodding and obscure
In unrewarded zeal, distinct and pure.
Maxwell Bodenheim

Dear Jack,

   I'm going to buy Doug Wixson a beer for handing you Trees in the Same Forest.  It came by a worthy messenger which is the best introduction.   Thank you for the warm letter and encouragement.   Mrs. ?Frany? at the West End is marvelous traveling for a lady who never made it to the South Side of St. Louis that is.  Doug told me you had lived in Chicago for many years, my birthplace.   I lived there from '45 til '63 with time out for a couple of yers outside St. Louis and again on the far side of the Atlantic.   Anyway I used to frequent 2nd City but it was a couple of generations after the gang of geniuses you mentioned.  I lived in LaGrange and a year at 23rd & Hayne amidst the best Italian Lithuanian Mexican restaurants you could find and me the only Irishman.  Since then Kansas where I was visiting when you came to Rolla and the Ozarks for the last nine years.  There's my geography and greetings to you

with many wishes for good health and an exciting time in Kansas City when you read there.  

   I enjoyed your columns in the Foolkiller.  I had seen the one on Thomas Hart Benton and we have the book you reviewed.  Next semester I'm going to teach a course on "Painters & Literature," a good excuse to look at a lot of paintings.   I'm planning on taking the group up to Jeff for a look at the murals.   Got any favorite painters in literature?  I'm still filling out my syllabus.   So far The Horse's Mouth, William Carlos Williams Pictures from Breughel, some of Browning's poems, Blake, and a few more.
   Say, don't let those guys give you Geritol, make them come across with some Jameson's or Powers or at least Old Overholt. 
   I'm going to send some pieces to the Foolkiller on your suggestions and I sure appreciate the direction.  Please to find enclosed a tall tale about a baseball player  I'm sure you have heard of, the immortal Jungle Jim Rivera of the Chicago White Sox;  and one you don't know, name of Fred Williams, in the same class as Mrs. Frany, local legend and what the hell here comes Sassafras too.
   I hope to find time in the near future to journey to Moberley to see you, until then sweet dreams + happy impulses,

Jim Bogan

Dear Jack -

  Seems like we've got work on our hands.  Doubleday is very high on the migration book.  It's up to us to salvage as much of the Chicago material as we can and then build on that as a foundation.   I have already begun, and Charles S. Johnson tells me of much material in his department at Fisk.
  I have a few ideas, too --

1)  How about several chapters about notable families who migrated?  Like the Caytons who went to the north-west, for example.  I have just done a more child-like chapter about them for my career book.  But there is good material in their story.
2)  I am planning an article on The Two Harlems - my own first impression (1924) and the present - which could be re-worked for another.
3)  The John Jones story could be revised to become a migration story of the early period.
4) Also, perhaps, our underground railroad stuff could become a migratory manifestation.
